Luis tiene tres hijos, el menor solo tiene 3 años, pero como esta separado con su esposa el niño más joven vive con ella, mientras que los otros dos viven con el. Por ahora sus ganancias le alcanza justo para cubrir los gastos de la críanza de los niños.
texts.en:
Luis works two jobs in order to support his two young children. When there are construction projects available, Luis works as a construction worker. When there are no projects, Luis sells DVDs and CDs at the market. In the future Luis would like to own his own store because he would have a stable job and be able to work everyday.

Luis has three children. The youngest is 3 years old. He is separated from his wife and his youngest child lives with her, while the other two live with him. For now, his earnings barely allow him to provide for his children.

(Translated by Elliot of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more tapes and CDs to sell

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam, 36, is married to Samuel M., a farmer. They are blessed with five children, Raymond, 21 years old, a tricycle driver who he did not finish his high school due to financial difficulties; Mary Rose, 17 years old, fourth year high school student; Mary Ann, 15 years old, already married in her very young age; Marimar, 8 years old, grade three pupil; and the youngest is Samuel M. Jr., 3 years old. The family lives in the semi- urban village of Del Pilar Alicia, Isabela. 

Miriam manages a village store in which retails different merchandise and vegetables displayed in front of her store. Miriam has successfully maintained her business for already 10 years now. She wants to avail a loan worth PHP8,000 to further expand her village store and purchase for business stocks in bulk also to increase her weekly net income of PHP800 that is budgeted for the daily allowances of her children and their basic needs at home.  The additional capital she wanted to avail will be of big help in improving her business towards uplifting their current living situation and continuing to send her children to school. “Believing in yourself and to God, all things are possible”, concluded Miriam.

loans.use: Expansion of village store and purchase of additional mechandise for sale

loans.name: Tham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Thắm, 27 tuổi, sống ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Gia đình chị có 2 con nhỏ còn đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1998 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Hiện nay bên cạnh chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn có thêm nghề làm đậu phụ. Anh Quân chồng chị ngoài thời gian phụ giúp vợ còn tranh thủ đi làm thuê để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình Với mức thu nhập bình quân  5.000.000/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Thắnm đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn và mua nguyên liệu về làm đậu bán
texts.en:
Ms. Tham Thi N. is a 27 years old woman in Me Linh, Hanoi. She has two children still going to school. Joining the TYM fund in 1998, she borrowed money to raise pigs. Besides, she also makes tofu. Her husband, Mr. Quan, is a seasonal worker. With the income of about 5,000,000 VND per month, their living condition is improving. Ms. Tham wants to borrow 10,000,000 VND to buy pigs and material to make tofu.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs and buy material

loans.name: Maher

texts.en:
Maher is a 45-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Maher has been working as a car painter since 1983. Maher requested a loan of 2200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his business. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.
His previous loans helped him improve his work as well as his financial situation. Maher is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he had to face the competition. Maher decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his financial situation as well as have independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his business.

loans.name: Ruth Saana's Group

texts.en:
Ruth Saana N. is the leader of the Nezikokolima Kitega group. She is a tailor with a tailoring business in Kitega. Ruth makes clothes of all kinds, mostly making ladies and children's clothing for sale. She also sells clothing material from her business.

How Ruth’s business operates is that she buys materials from Kampala and brings them to her business in Kitega Some customers come and choose which ones to sew for them, while others come with their own materials for the same sewing.

This is her third loan with the group and she has been able to rise from 300,000 shillings to a million now. She is seeing the change in her business because now she has more clothes for sale, more customers, and more profits. She needs a new loan to buy more clothes and threads for sale. Ruth dreams of having many sewing machines and employing other people and, in the end, forming a sewing and tailoring school.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials and threads for sewing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To make and sell palm oil

loans.name: Razia Shoqat Group

texts.en:
Razia S. baji is an unmarried lady who has lived in Borewala, Pakistan, for the last ten years. Borewala is famous for its shrines. Razia baji operates a clothes-sewing business. She chose this business to keep herself busy. Now she enjoys doing this work because she feels independent.

Her father runs a medical store in the community. He has six years of experience in this business. She is applying for a loan to buy medicines to increase the profit of her father’s medical store.

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality:

Ramzan baji wans a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell.

Mumtaz A. baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

loans.use: To buy medicines for her father's medical store

loans.name: Samba

texts.fr:
MR SAMBA K. est un membre de la mutuelle depuis deux ans ;il est agent de facturation à la société des eaux de thiès et parallèlement à ses activités il fait du commerce ;par un intermédiaire il achète des produits comme l'huile de palme et la pate d'arachide qu'il place auprès de la clientèle
avec le pret qu'il sollicite il veut renforcer son fonds de roulement
texts.en:
Mr. Samba K. has been a member of the credit union for 2 years. He works in billing in the water company in Thiès, and at the same time, he works as a merchant. He has someone buy products such as palm oil and peanut butter for him and he gets them to the customers.

With the loan, he hopes to increase his working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying and selling products

loans.name: Abong

texts.en: L. is single with four children. She lives in Ntamulung quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. L. and her entire family live in a house with eight rooms, one sitting room and a kitchen. Being a very hard working woman, L. had to overcome some challenges in life such as taking care of her children, especially as she is living in her parents house. It is not easy for her living there with other family members and children. L. runs a call centre, an embroidery business and also sells food supplements in front of their compound with the support of her children. She plans to invest this loan in her existing businesses of call centre, food supplement and embroidery. She plans to expand these businesses since she has been doing them for a number of years. This will be L.’s fourth loan from GHAPE; she has been a member since 2005. She has been quite successful in the past with her businesses due to her location (right on the main road), the quality of her products, and her reasonable prices. Also, with her experience, she is now having more customers who buy her products. Part of her profits from this loan will be used to buy a plot where she will construct a house in the future for her and the children. And another part will be used to improve her farm. L. does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments as they are quite small repayments every month. She intends to start repayment in the fourth month after taking the loan. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy food supplements, material for embroidery and farm supplies and to pay operating costs of a call centre

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul A. sells rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories. He hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories to sell. He is 30 years old and single without children. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is 45 years old and married with 4 children. She sells foodstuffs in the market. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She say thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake sells fish in the market. She wants to expand her business. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more fish to sell. She is 53 years old and married with 3 children. She hopes to give her children a quality education. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver G. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Oliver is 39 years old and a widow. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a 46-year-old widow with five children aged between 15 and 23 years, all of whom go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house in the outskirts of Kampala where she lives with six people. She also takes care of additional family members.

Agnes owns a stall at her home where she sells charcoal. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for three years and is servicing her sixth loan. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises because she works from her home.

Agnes sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale. She buys sacks of charcoal from Kyankwanzi in Mubende district and so she incurs transport costs to and from villages. Her challenges include transportation and the rainy season.

Agnes wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow stronger and to begin selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Jocye

texts.en:
Joyce is 30 years old and married with three children between the ages of 2 and 11 years. All her children go to school. Joyce takes care of additional family members. She rents a three-room house where she lives with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water.

Joyce has a salon where she sells hair extensions and cosmetics. She pays for transportation costs to and from her work. On average, she receives 30 customers a day. She works in Kampala city.

Joyce has been in this business for six years and with the Kiva field partner, MCDT, for nine years, now servicing her twentieth loan and working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family, accommodation and medication. Her business challenges include the increasing prices of cosmetics and defaulters.

She wants to use this loan to buy more hair extensions and boxes of cosmetics. She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more hair extensions and boxes of cosmetics

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena C. is a 39-year-old general store owner who has also been in the canteen business for ten years. She lives with her three children among the poor communities in Camarin, Caloocan City.

Rowena loves to cook and serve food to her neighbors along with tending the general store, which gives her an income of more than PHP 14,000 a month. She hires an assistant from the neighborhood to help her tend to customers, especially on busy days.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for four years now. Rowena is already on her 8th loan cycle. She needs a loan in the amount of PHP 17,000 to sustain her store and food business.

She dreams of having her own restaurant someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Grocery items and recipe ingredients

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
31-year-old Joan is the mother of two. She has been married for seven years. Joan’s business is rice farming. She shared that her business is productive now and hopes to maintain it this way.

A member of the Kiva field partner, CEVI, for three years now, she can say that its program is really helpful to farmers like her. She is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use this loan to buy gasoline for her tractor and to acquire farm supplies needed at her farm. This loan will help sustain Joan’s business.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de commerce. 
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, elles achèteront,  une grande quantité de différentes sortes de condiments alimentaires, des céréales et des habillements. 
Les condiments et les habillements sont achetés en gros à Bamako et les céréales sont achetées aux environs du village et le tout  est revendu au marché de Fana  au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de  35.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre  la nourriture, la santé et la réutilisation dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of Benkadi Group are married women who, on average, are 38 years old and have four children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Fantombougou, subprefecture of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro of the Republic of Mali. They have known each other through neighborhood and business links.

They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure a continuous financial support to their activities. This is their seventh solidarity loan. They have repaid all their previous loans on schedule.

As regards this new loan, the group members will buy a large quantity of food condiments, cereals and clothes. The condiments and clothes will be bought wholesale in Bamako, whereas the cereals will be bought in the surrounding countryside. They will resell all this at the market in Fana, located next to the tarred road, to a clientele made up of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 CFA francs each. They will spend part of their profit on food and healthcare and reinvest part of it in their businesses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, cereals and clothes

loans.name: Oyebola

texts.en:
Oyebola is married to a civil servant and resides in Lagos. She is 40 years old and has three children. She is a member of the Kiva field partner, LAPO. Oyebola raises poultry, selling birds as well as eggs, and supplies her eggs to traders in large quantities.

She says her greatest challenges are insufficient capital to expand her business, purchasing sick chickens without knowing it, and the transportation costs, which are very high in the area due to her traveling to selling centers.

Oyebola needs a loan of 170,000 NGN to increase her inventory by purchasing more chicks to raise, with the aim of selling them to make more profit.

loans.use: To purchase more nursery birds for her poultry farm

loans.name: Fernando Jose

texts.es:
El    Señor Fernando José P. R., Labora como Responsable de Mantenimiento del Instituto Manuel Olivares Rodríguez  de Managua, ella tiene dos  hijos a su cargo, y  esto se encuentra en edad escolar, esta casada, ha trabajado  créditos con CEPRODEL durante tres  años, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido tres créditos  en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.  

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: zinc y perlines por lo que va a cambiar una parte del techo de su casa el que se encuentra en  mal estado.

Con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos. 

 Fernando dijo que gracias a los préstamos  otorgados por ceprodel ha podido mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Sr. Fernando José P. R. is in charge of maintenance for the Manuel Olivares Rodríguez Institute in Managua. He is married and has two dependent children attending school. Fernando has been working with CEPRODEL for the past three years. During this time, he has received three home improvement loans.

The loan he is now requesting will be used to buy construction materials, such as zinc and crossbeams, to replace part of the roof of his house since it is bad condition. His objective is to provide greater security and better living conditions for his children. Fernando thanks CEPRODEL for providing the loans that make it possible for him to improve his home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Roof repairs

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en:
Elchin R. is a 34-year-old entrepreneur who is married with two children. He has ten years of experience in selling women’s and children’s clothes and has his own store in his home city, called Agsu. He is very experienced in choosing clothes which are in very high demand.

From the day his first child came into this world he gave his word that his children will never be without bread and he has kept that word and tries his best every day to provide the best education and the best food for his beloved kids. He goes to work at 6 a.m. and finishes his work late at 10 p.m.

Elchin applied for 1,600 AZN in order to purchase more spring clothes. Let’s do our best to help this man who gave his heart to his children.

loans.use: To purchase women's spring clothes

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S. is 30 years old, married, and has three children. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Since 2009 she has been engaged in the agricultural sector of farming, earning approximately $1 USD per day. Through this business, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. The family's standard of living has improved since S. started her business.
S.'s husband is a recycler, earning an income of $3 USD per day. S. is now requesting a loan of $500 USD to expand her husband's business and purchase more recyclable materials for sale. This is her first loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more recyclable materials for sale

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: LA SRA. ROSA VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE LA GUARDIA DISTANTE A 20 KM DE LA CIUDAD DE SANTA CRUZ, ESTA CASADA TIENE UN HIJO A SU CARGO YA QUE LOS DEMAS SON MAYORES E INDEPENDIENTES, YA CASADOS TODOS ELLOS, LA SRA, ROSA TIENE QUE TRABAJAR VENDIENDO ROPA, POR QUE LOS INGRESO GENERADOS POR SU ESPOSO NO LE ALCANSAN PARA CUBRIR SUS NECESIDADES, SUS DESEO ES TENER UN PUESTO FIJO EN EL MERCADO CENTRAL, PARA NO TENER QUE AMBULAR POR LAS CALLES, EL DINERO DEL CREDITO LO INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE MERCADERIA Y ASI PODER INCREMENTAR SU CAPITAL DE TRABAJO, ES UNA PERSONA RESPONSABLE Y DINAMICA Y MUY TRABAJADORA, ESTA AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Rosa lives in La Gurdia, which is 20 kilometers from the city of Santa Cruz. She is married and has just one son under her care; the others are all adult, married and independent. Rosa works selling clothing because her husband's income is insufficient to meet all household needs. She hopes to have a fixed sales location inside the central market so that she doesn't have to peddle in the streets anymore. She will use the funds to buy merchandise to increase her working capital. She is a responsible, dynamic, very hard-working person. She is grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in her by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Feliuai

texts.en:
Feliai A. is 29 and married with 4 children (ages 1 - 7).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Feliai has many years of experience in this business.  Feliai needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Feliai joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Feliai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Feliai A. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: La Familia Renacer 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Anita is the coordinator of her group La Familia Renacer (The Family is Reborn), and her story is representative of the members of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, a city known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Anita is excited to be taking out her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a colmado, or small general store, by stocking rice, beans, cooking oil, spaghetti, sauces, and flour as well as a freezer in which to store goods. She will use the profits to save towards her dream of one day opening a supermarket. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: rice, beans, cooking oil, spaghetti, sauces, and flour and a freezer

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the village of Bocator Tangub City. She is 32 years-old and married with three school-aged children. Evelyn owns and operates a  specialized retail store which sells daily use products such as candies, eggs, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Evelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items.

loans.name: Edmalin's Group

texts.en:
Edmalin E. is from the village of Centro Sur, Amulung, Cagayan. She is 30 years old and the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Edmalin is married and has 1 infant. She owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Edmalin has been involved in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Edmalin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edmalin has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Edmalin is requesting a new loan, her 2nd, of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nilufar's Group

texts.en:
Nilufar O. is the leader of this group and she is 35 years old. To make some money, her husband went to work in Russia. Nilufar has two daughters and a son. All of them study at school. Two years ago with an initial investment of 1200 soms, Nilufar started to sell potatoes and cherries.  She made good money and from that moment, Nilufar began to sell fruits and vegetables. Now she makes 5000 soms per month. With this profit, she was able to save money to repair the house and purchase a TV and DVD player. Nilufar wants to get a loan to purchase different fruits and vegetables in order to resell them and make a profit. In the future, she plans to stabilize her business, to pay a dowry for her daughters and build a sauna.

Umidahon S. is 35. Her husband is a farmer. She has three sons who are currently students. Twelve years ago with an initial investment of 1800 soms, Umidahon bought a calf and started breeding cattle. In this way, she makes 2500 soms per month. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase a bull, which will be resold after fattening. In the future, Umidahon would like to open a kiosk near her house.

Sayorahon R. is 28. Her husband works as a constructor and they have two sons, who are in kindergarten. Sayorahon works in a barbershop. With money received from the loan, she plans to purchase cement and other building materials in order to continue repairing the house.

Nafisahon S. is 26. In order to make some money, her husband went to work in Russia. They have a daughter and a son; both are currently in preschool. Nafisahon breeds, fattens and resells cattle and poultry. In this way, she makes 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Nafisahon wants to purchase a bull-calf and resell it after fattening. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase different fruits and vegetables in order to resell them and make a profit

loans.name: Pal

texts.en:
Pal P., 32, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

P. sells fish for a gross income of about USD 50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4.30 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more fish to sell.

In the future, P. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en: Mrs. Nirmala M., 35 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Thecho is one of the less developed areas of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs.M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 10 and the younger son is studying in grade 6. Her husband's name is Tari Babu M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture-making shop 9 years ago. All the requirements of their family must be met with only the shop’s income. With her loan from Kiva, her husband was able to purchase wood supplies for her small furniture shop. Now Mrs. M. is requesting a second loan of NPR 10,000 to buy timber to be able to fill their orders for furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture such as beds, tables, chairs, and wardrobes.

loans.use: To buys wood for furniture making.

loans.name: Vannak's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people which located in Chong Kaoh village, Kanal province. Mrs. Vannak M. is 47 years old and is the group leader having been selected by its four members. While each While each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purpose.
Mrs. Vannak M. and her husband, Mrs. Sokly Moeun, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate vegetable for a living. In order to support this farm, Mrs. Vannak M. will use the loan to buy a water machine and to buy a hose to water plants. Aside from farmers, they are also bean sprout and leek seller in the local market who are able to earn a small income to improve their family living. This couple has three children, who all are seamstresses in the garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a water machine and to buy a hose

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos B., from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental, is 42 years old and single. To make a living, Carlos owns and operates a business venture raising pigs for sale. Engaged in his business for over 14 years, he earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Carlos joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future, he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and more timber

loans.name: Rosevilla

texts.en:
Rosevilla N. is from the village of Siparok. She is 44 years old. Rosevilla is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Rosevilla owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Rosevilla has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosevilla joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosevilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Rosevilla is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing supplies for their boat. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rosevilla from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing supplies for their boat.

location.town: Liloy-Siparok, Jose Dalman, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia A. sells slippers and fish at Elmina. Patricia has no formal educational background. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a plumber. She has been selling slippers and fish for six years now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more slippers for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to revive her fish business.

loans.use: buy more slippers for sale

loans.name: Romulo

texts.es: Romulo Tiene 53 años, el tiene ya 12 años en el negocio de la tapiceria y carpinteria, tiene su negocio instalado en su vivienda, el cual le permite tener buenos ingresos, el tiene un hijo el cual se encuenta en edad escolar, Romulo desea comprar material que le sirva para la implementación de su negocio y así darle todo lo mejor a su hijo, por lo cual trabaja con mucho esfuerzo, para cambiar su  la calidad de vida, por lo que se le brinda el crédito por contar con capacidad de pago y además por contar con buenas referencias personales.
texts.en:
Rómulo, 53, has had an upholstery and carpentry shop set up in his home for 12 years that produces good income.  He has a school aged son.

Rómulo wants to buy supplies to stock his business and give the best to his son.  To reach this goal he works hard to change his quality of life.

The loan is approved because he has the ability to pay and because he has good personal references.

loans.use: To buy supplies.

loans.name: Mayleen Malana's Group

texts.en:
Mayleen M. is 21 years old, married and has two infant-aged children. She is from Cataggaman Nuevo in Tuguegarao City, Cagayan province in the Luzon islands. Mayleen is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Mayleen makes and sells primarily fish balls and other dimsums to the local community. She has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Mayleen joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Mayleen is requesting a loan, her first from ASKI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional foods to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional food products to sell

loans.name: Badamhand

texts.en: Badamhand T. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three daughters in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home, in the Suhbaatar province of Mongolia. All her daughters, ages 11, 16 and 18, attend a local secondary school. Her husband, Batdorj, operates a taxi service after purchasing his motorcycle for 500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) from an individual. Badamhand operates a dairy-product trading business in her town. Her husband's sibling is a herder in the countryside and owns 120 livestock. She owns a cow with three calves that produces the milk and she sells it to stores. She has been operating her business since 2004 and has gained significant experience and built a stable operation. Badamhand is a hardworking and diligent person. For the future, she plans to buy a new car for her husband's transportation business and build a house for her family. She says, "I (have) plans to build a house and to purchase and preserve more dairy products at (a) wholesale price before such products grow scarce." Badamhand is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan to purchase large amount of dairy products from herders and to buy construction materials for her house.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of dairy products

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun S., 33, is married with two young children living at home in Takeo province. She works in a garment factory, typically making US$3.50 each day and her husband, pictured here, is a taxi driver. Her husband typically makes about US$4 each day.

Hun S. would like a loan of US$1000 to open her new business. She has been working in a garment factory for years, so she is sure that she can open a tailor shop. This money will help her open a tailor shop.

loans.use: To open a tailor shop.
